**Survey & Microdata:**

1. [World Bank Microdata Library (catalog 5911 example)](https://microdata.worldbank.org/index.php/catalog/5911/get-microdata) - Household and health survey microdata (FREE with registration)
2. [DHS Program: Stata Indicator Library](https://github.com/DHSProgram/DHS-Indicators-Stata) - Stata code templates for DHS survey indicators (FREE)

**Streaming & Real-Time Data:**

1. [Awesome Public Real-Time Datasets](https://github.com/bytewax/awesome-public-real-time-datasets) - Curated feeds for streaming and pipeline projects (FREE)
2. [OpenSky Network API](https://opensky-network.org/apidoc/) - Live air traffic data (FREE)
3. [USGS Earthquake API](https://earthquake.usgs.gov/fdsnws/event/1/) - Near real-time seismic data (FREE)
4. [Transport for London Unified API](https://api.tfl.gov.uk/) - Live transport status (FREE with key)

**Setup notes (real-time feeds):**

- Quarto can mix R and Python chunks; use `httr2`/`jsonlite` in R or `requests` in Python for GET calls.
- Most APIs return JSON; wrap responses into `tibble::as_tibble()` or `pandas.DataFrame` for quick plotting.
- OpenSky and USGS require no keys for basic use; TfL needs a free app key (register, set as env var `TFL_APP_KEY`).
- For streaming experiments, pair the Bytewax list with `websocket`/`httpuv` in R or `websockets`/`asyncio` in Python.

**Open Practice Datasets:**

1. [Kaggle Datasets](https://www.kaggle.com/datasets) - Community datasets for modeling and dashboards (FREE)
2. [Google Dataset Search](https://datasetsearch.research.google.com/) - Search engine for open datasets (FREE)
3. [Data.gov](https://catalog.data.gov/dataset) - US government open data (FREE)
4. [data.europa.eu](https://data.europa.eu/en) - European Union open data portal (FREE)
5. [Registry of Open Data on AWS](https://registry.opendata.aws/) - Ready-to-use public datasets in the cloud (FREE)

### **Sample Project Ideas (R, Python, SQL in Quarto)** {.project-card}

1. **Flight traffic monitor (OpenSky API + R/Python):** Pull live flights every 60 seconds, cache to SQLite with `DBI::dbWriteTable()` or `pandas.to_sql()`, then map routes with `leaflet` (R) or `plotly` (Python).
2. **Earthquake alert map (USGS + R):** Fetch last 24h quakes, bucket magnitudes in dplyr, visualize with `ggplot2`/`geom_point()` and annotate cities; add a SQL chunk to aggregate by country from SQLite.
3. **Transit reliability dashboard (TfL + SQL):** Collect bus arrival predictions to a Postgres/SQLite table, compute headway irregularity via SQL window functions, chart peak-hour gaps with `ggplot2` or `seaborn`.
4. **Streaming sentiment mini-pipeline (Bytewax list + Python):** Pick any public websocket feed, stream into DuckDB using `duckdb` Python API, run live SQL for hourly aggregates, and render in a Quarto page.
5. **Household survey microdata cleaner (DHS/MICS + R + SQL):** Use DHS Stata templates for indicator definitions, import microdata with `haven`, stage to DuckDB via `dbplyr`, and build a reproducible ETL Quarto doc with R/Python chunks side by side.

## **üìñ My Recommendations**

::: {.highlight-box}
### **If I were starting over in data analytics, here's what I'd focus on:**

**Months 1-3: Foundations**
1. Learn SQL (SQLBolt + Mode tutorials)
2. Pick ONE language: R OR Python
3. Master Excel/Google Sheets
4. Learn basic statistics (Khan Academy)
5. Build 3 simple projects

**Months 4-6: Intermediate Skills**
1. Data visualization (ggplot2 or matplotlib)
2. Exploratory data analysis
3. Statistical inference
4. Git & GitHub basics
5. Build portfolio website
6. Complete 2-3 Kaggle competitions

**Months 7-9: Specialization**
1. Choose domain (health, finance, marketing)
2. Learn domain-specific tools
3. Machine learning basics
4. Dashboard building (Tableau/Power BI)
5. Write 5 blog posts explaining projects

**Months 10-12: Job Ready**
1. Advanced analytics projects
2. Real-world datasets (not just tutorials)
3. Practice interviews (technical + behavioral)
4. Network on LinkedIn
5. Apply to entry-level roles
6. Consider freelancing for experience

**Key principle:** **Build projects, not just skills. Employers hire problem-solvers.**
:::
